bad.work: Satan in His Original Glory: 'Thou Wast Perfect Till Iniquity Was Found in Thee'

title.reg: Satan in His Original Glory: 'Thou Wast Perfect Till Iniquity Was Found in Thee'

titlestmt.title: Satan in His Original Glory: "Thou Wast Perfect Till Iniquity Was Found in Thee" : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 8KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 107KB to 1200KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesMarch 2010
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of 20 of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. These designs illustrate the Old Testament and are arranged according to the passages illustrated. They are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
The Bible had an enormous influence on Blake’s work as both artist and poet. Among his many and complex responses to that text are water color drawings. The present group of 20 is selected from a sequence of about 80 biblical water colors of similar size Blake painted for Thomas Butts between c. 1800 and c. 1806. These designs emphasize interactions between the human and the divine. In works such as Ezekiel’s Wheels and David Delivered Out of Many Waters, the interaction is revelatory or redemptive. In other designs, including Pestilence: The Death of the First-Born, the relationship between God and humankind devolves into punishment and destruction.
This group of 20 water colors is the first installment in our publication of a large selection of Blake’s water color drawings illustrating the Bible. In coming months we will publish a group of New Testament illustrations also from the series executed for Butts. Later we will add early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, including Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes of c. 1824.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

title.hi: Satan in His Original Glory: "Thou Wast Perfect Till Iniquity Was Found in Thee"

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1805; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; offered at Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 157, titled "Thou wast perfect till iniquity was found in thee" (10s. to "Butts," thus indicating that the lot was bought-in if Butts was the vendor); offered from the Butts collection, Foster & Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 103 (not sold; bought-in at 11s.), and at Foster & Son, 8 March 1854, lot 14, with two other works by Blake (not sold; bought-in at 10s.); by inheritance to Captain Frederick J. Butts; his widow; sold April 1906 through Carfax & Co. to W. Graham Robertson; sold from his collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 23 (£1260 to the executors of Robertson's estate for presentation through the National Art-Collections Fund to the Tate Gallery, now Tate Collection).

objtitle.title: Satan in His Original Glory: "Thou Wast Perfect Till Iniquity Was Found in Thee"

objnote.p: Blake signed the work lower right with his monogram; see the textual transcription. Inscribed, not by Blake, on a prior and damaged mat, "Thou wast perfect...", part of the text from Ezekiel 27, and "Ezekiel ch. 28.th v. 13.th...."

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is based in part on Ezekiel 28:14-15. Dominating this design is the figure of an angelic, not-yet-fallen Satan or Lucifer. He stands or hovers, facing forward. He is nude, but has multiple sets of wings, one of which covers his genitals. His hair is short and curly and topped by a flame-like crown with vegetative forms topped with a star or blossom. A strap, as if for a quiver or a sash of honor, runs diagonally across his chest. His left leg is bent backward and on tiptoe. His arms are raised at 45 degrees. In his right hand he holds an orb topped with a cross. In his left hand he holds a scepter topped with a fleur-de-lis. Satan appears to be suspended in space, perhaps with clouds surrounding him. He may also emanate an aura around his head and with beams of light angling downward lower right and left. By his feet are at least 45 stars, 16 planets (including Saturn with its rings), and one crescent moon. A variety of small figures surround Satan. Near his right hand are eight hovering or flying figures. The top right figure appears to be that of a gowned male with short hair. His legs are extended behind him and his arms are crossed as he faces left and down slightly. To the left of the cross on the orb is a figure of indeterminable gender, facing right and slightly up. Its right arm is raised horizontally and its legs are spread. It may be nude. To the left of the orb held in Satan's right hand is a figure sitting, hunched forward. It is of indeterminable gender and wears a gown as it faces forward and down. Its legs are bent to support a book on its lap, from which it apparently reads. Beneath the reading figure, and perhaps supporting it, is another figure of indeterminable gender, facing forward and right. Its arms are raised at 135 degrees and bent as though supporting the book on the other figure's lap. It may be gowned and have short hair. To the left of the reading figure is another flying figure of indeterminable gender, which may wear a gown and have short hair. It faces left and away, with its body twisted to face up. Its legs are together and its arms are raised vertically. To the left of this flying figure are two small figures, perhaps cherubs or children. The leftmost figure's body is horizontal as it flies left and slightly down. Its legs are spread slightly and its arm is raised horizontally. Its gender is indeterminable, but it may be gowned. The rightmost figure of this pair faces forward and may look up and to the right. Its gender is also indeterminable. Beneath Satan's right hand is the figure of a male, facing forward. He may wear breeches or pants, but his upper body is nude. He has short hair and bends his legs behind him. His arms are at his side and hold an indeterminable object, perhaps a stone pillar. Beneath this figure are three flames. To the left of Satan's right leg hover thirteen small figures. Two figures hold and perhaps play large tambourines. Both figures may be gowned and have short hair, though their gender is indeterminable. The leftmost figure faces left and up, with its right arm raised vertically. The rightmost figure faces left and up. To the left of the tambourine players are two figures playing trumpets or horns. The leftmost figure is bald and faces forward and down with his(?) arms bent to hold the horn to his mouth. His lower body seems to be made of or perhaps shrouded in cloud. The rightmost figure has long hair and faces right and down, with her(?) arms bent upward to hold a horn to her mouth. To the left of these trumpeters are two more figures, seated on a cloud. The leftmost figure of the pair appears to be a female, partly clothed by a skirt or cloth secured around her waist. She has long hair pulled up into a bun and sits, hunched over, with her legs bent, facing left and down. The rightmost figure is of indeterminable gender, but faces forward and right. It may be wrapped in a cloth or drapery. To the left of Satan's right foot is a pair of figures embracing. The leftmost figure is nude and faces right and down, looking away at the figure to the right. His right arm is raised vertically (relative to his body) and points. The rightmost figure faces right and up and may be gowned. Her left arm is bent upward, almost vertically, and points. To the left of these embracing figures are a set of three trumpeters or horn players, all gowned and with curly hair. The leftmost trumpeter faces down and left and extends his(?) left arm horizontally, with his right arm bent upward, holding the horn to his mouth. The middle figure faces down and slightly forward, with his body facing left and with both arms raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. The rightmost figure faces down and forward, with his body facing left, and both arms raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. Above these trumpeters are a pair of gowned figures with curly hair, but of indeterminable gender. The leftmost figure faces forward and down, with its left leg extended out behind it. Its right arm is bent upward and it points with its right hand. It may be looking at the trumpeters. The rightmost figure faces forward and right, with its left arm raised horizontally and perhaps pointing and its right arm bent upward to hold a large book. To the right of Satan's left leg is a group of six figures. The uppermost pair of figures sits on a cloud. The leftmost figure faces forward and right and is of indeterminable gender. It may look at the figure to its right. The rightmost figure of the pair appears to be that of a male with a beard and wearing a gown. His body is twisted so that the lower half faces up and left while the upper half faces forward and right. His knees are bent and he reclines on a book. His right arm points down and he may hold a pen or quill in his right hand. His right arm is bent and his hand rests on the book. To the right of Satan's foot is a set of three trumpeters, perhaps all male and gowned with long hair. All of their eyes may be closed. The leftmost trumpeter faces right and down, though his lower body is twisted to face up and left. His right arm is raised horizontally to hold the horn to his mouth. The middle trumpeter faces right, with his left arm raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. The rightmost trumpeter may have curly hair, and faces right and down, with his right arm raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. Below the trumpeter descends a male(?) nude holding a book in his bent left arm and pointing down with his right. His legs are bent above him. Surrounding the scepter held in Satan's left hand is a group of six figures. The uppermost two sit on a cloud and are of indeterminable gender. The leftmost of the pair wears a gown and faces left and forward, though with its head turned to face right and down, perhaps looking at the figure to its right. Its arms may be crossed and it is standing or walking on the cloud. The rightmost figure of this pair sits, facing right and forward, and looking down at a book or tablet that it holds on its lap. Its left leg is bent and drawn up to support the book, and its arms are bent to hold the book. Three figures cling to the scepter. The leftmost figure is nude and appears to be a male cherub or child with short hair, seen from behind, though also facing right slightly. Its legs are bent behind it and its arms are bent upward. The middle figure may be a female with long hair pulled up into a bun. She faces right and down, though with her head turned to look left, perhaps at the cherub to her left. She may wear a gown. The rightmost clinging figure faces left and up, with her legs extended behind her. She has long hair and wears a gown, and is seen from behind. Her arms are raised horizontally. Beneath the group clinging to the scepter is the figure of a gowned female (perhaps only clothed by a skirt or cloth secured around her waist). She sits on a cloud, facing left and down slightly. She hunches or bends forward, with her arms extended horizontally, to hold onto a long scroll. Below the scroll and scepter is a group of five figures. The uppermost figure appears to be that of a gowned male with short hair, sitting on a cloud and facing forward and slightly left. He is hunched or bent forward and looks down at an open book that he holds on his drawn-up knees. Holding on to the end of the scroll with her(?) right hand is a gowned figure (perhaps only clothed from the waist down) with short hair. She faces left and slightly forward, with her arms raised at 135 degrees. She may look up. Below the figure holding on to the scroll is a nude or partly nude female(?) figure with long hair. Her body faces right and down, though her head faces left. Her right arm is raised horizontally to hold onto an upside down cross or small sword, wrapped around with cloth. Beneath the cross or sword are two gowned male(?) figures with short hair. The uppermost one faces right and down, though his body is twisted to face left. He holds a tube, pillar, or rolled scroll. The lowermost figure also holds a tube, pillar, or rolled scroll and is facing down and away, with his(?) left arm bent upward around the tube. The background sky is dark. The scene may take place in heaven since Lucifer is not yet fallen. The blue strip at the bottom of the design was formerly covered by a mat; hence, this area did not fade.

component.illusobjdesc: Dominating this design is the figure of an angelic, not-yet-fallen Satan or Lucifer. He stands or hovers, facing forward. He is nude, but has multiple sets of wings, one of which covers his genitals. His hair is short and curly and topped by a flame-like crown with vegetative forms topped by a star or blossom. A strap, as if for a quiver or a sash of honor, runs diagonally across his chest. His left leg is bent backward and on tiptoe. His arms are raised at 45 degrees. In his right hand he holds a orb topped with a cross. In his left hand he holds a scepter topped with a fleur-de-lis. Lucifer may emanate an aura of light around his head and with beams of light angling downward lower right and left.
In his right hand Satan holds an orb topped with a cross. In his left hand he holds a scepter topped with a fleur-de-lis.

Satan appears to be suspended in space, perhaps with clouds surrounding him. He may also emanate an aura. By his feet are at least 45 stars, 16 planets (including Saturn with its rings), and one very small crescent moon.

A variety of small figures surround Satan. Near his right hand are eight hovering or flying figures. The top right figure appears to be that of a gowned male with short hair. His legs are extended behind him and his arms are crossed as he faces left and down slightly. To the left of the cross on the orb is a figure of indeterminable gender, facing right and slightly up. Its right arm is raised horizontally and its legs are spread. It may be nude. To the left of the orb held in Satan's right hand is a figure sitting, hunched forward. It is of indeterminable gender and wears a gown as it faces forward and down. Its legs are bent to support a book on its lap, from which it probably reads. Beneath the reading figure, and perhaps supporting it, is another figure of indeterminable gender, facing forward and right. Its arms are raised at 135 degrees and bent as though supporting the book on the other figure's lap. It may be gowned and have short hair. To the left of the reading figure is another flying figure of indeterminable gender, which may wear a gown and have short hair. It faces left and away, with its body twisted to face up. Its legs are together and its arms are raised vertically. To the left of this flying figure are two small figures, perhaps cherubs or children. The leftmost figure's body is horizontal as it flies left and slightly down. Its legs are spread slightly and its arm is raised horizontally. Its gender is indeterminable, but it may be gowned. The rightmost figure of this pair faces forward and may look up and to the right. Its gender is also indeterminable. Beneath Satan's right hand is the figure of a male, facing forward. He may wear breeches or pants, but his upper body is nude. He has short hair and bends his legs behind him. His arms are at his side and hold an indeterminable object, perhaps a stone pillar. Beneath this figure are three flames.

A variety of small figures surround Satan. To the left of Satan's right leg hover thirteen small figures. Two figures hold and perhaps play large tambourines. Both figures may be gowned and have short hair, though their gender is indeterminable. The leftmost figure faces left and up, with its right arm raised vertically. The rightmost figure faces left and up. To the left of the tambourine players are two figures playing trumpets or horns. The leftmost figure is bald and faces forward and down with his(?) arms bent to hold the horn to his mouth. His lower body seems to be made of or perhaps shrouded in cloud. The rightmost figure has long hair and faces right and down, with his arms bent upward to hold a horn to his mouth. To the left of these trumpeters are two more figures, seated on a cloud. The leftmost figure of the pair appears to be a female, partly clothed by a skirt or cloth secured around her waist. She has long hair pulled up into a bun and sits, hunched over, with her legs bent, facing left and down. The rightmost figure is of indeterminable gender, but faces forward and right. It may be wrapped in a cloth or drapery with at least one arm wrapped around its body. To the left of Satan's left foot are a pair of figures embracing. The leftmost figure is nude and faces right and down, looking away at the figure to the right. His right arm is raised vertically (relative to his body) and points. The rightmost figure faces right and up and may be gowned. Her left arm is bent upward, almost vertically, and points. To the left of these embracing figures are a set of three trumpeters or horn players, all gowned and with curly hair. The leftmost trumpeter faces down and left and extends his(?) left arm horizontally, with his right arm bent upward, holding the horn to his mouth. The middle figure faces down and slightly forward, with his body facing left and with both arms raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. The rightmost figure faces down and forward, with his body facing left, and both arms raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. Above these trumpeters are a pair of gowned figures with curly hair, but of indeterminable gender. The leftmost figure faces forward and down, with its left leg extended out behind it. Its right arm is bent upward and it points with its right hand. It may be looking at the trumpeters. The rightmost figure faces forward and right, with its left arm raised horizontally and perhaps pointing and its right arm bent upward to hold a large book.

A variety of small figures surround Satan. To the right of Satan's left leg is a group of six figures. The uppermost pair of figures sits on a cloud. The leftmost figure faces forward and right and is of indeterminable gender. It may look at the figure to its right. The rightmost figure of the pair appears to be that of a male with a beard and wearing a gown. His body is twisted so that the lower half faces up and left while the upper half faces forward and right. His mouth may be open. His knees are bent and he reclines on an open book. His right arm points down and he may hold a pen or quill in his right hand. His right arm is bent and his hand rests on the book. To the right of Satan's foot is a set of three trumpeters, perhaps all male and gowned with long hair. All of their eyes may be closed. The leftmost trumpeter faces right and down, though his lower body is twisted to face up and left. His right arm is raised horizontally to hold the horn to his mouth. The middle trumpeter faces right, with his left arm raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. The rightmost trumpeter may have curly hair, and faces right and down, with his right arm raised horizontally to hold the trumpet to his mouth. Below the trumpeter is a descending nude male(?) holding a book in his raised left arm and pointing down with his right. His legs are bent upward behind him.

A variety of small figures surround Satan. Surrounding the scepter held in Satan's left hand is a group of six figures. The uppermost two sit on a cloud and are of indeterminable gender. The leftmost of the pair wears a gown and faces left and forward, though with its head turned to face right and down, perhaps looking at the figure to its right. Its arms may be crossed and it is standing or walking on the cloud. The rightmost figure of this pair sits, facing right and forward, and looking down at a book or tablet that it holds on its lap. Its left leg is bent and drawn up to support the book, and its arms are bent to hold the book. Three figures cling to the scepter. The leftmost figure is nude and appears to be a male cherub or child with short hair, seen from behind, though also facing right slightly. Its legs are bent behind it and its arms are bent upward. The middle figure may be a female with long hair pulled up into a bun. She faces right and down, though with her head turned to look left, perhaps at the cherub to her left. She may wear a gown. The rightmost clinging figure faces left and up, with her legs extended behind her. She has long hair and wears a gown, and is seen from behind. Her arms are raised horizontally. Beneath the group clinging to the scepter is the figure of a gowned female (perhaps only clothed by a skirt or cloth secured around her waist). She sits on a cloud, facing left and down slightly. She hunches or bends forward, with her arms extended horizontally, to hold onto a long scroll.

A variety of small figures surround Satan. Below the scroll and scepter is a group of five figures. The uppermost figure appears to be that of a gowned male with short hair, sitting on a cloud and facing forward and slightly left. He is hunched or bent forward and looks down at, and probably reads, an open book that he holds on his drawn-up knees. Holding on to the end of the scroll with his right hand is a gowned figure (perhaps only clothed from the waist down) with short hair. He faces left and slightly forward, with his arms raised at 135 degrees. He may look up. To the right of the figure holding on to the scroll is a nude or partly nude female(?) figure with long hair. Her body faces right and down, though her head faces left. Her right arm is raised horizontally to hold onto an upside down cross or small sword, wrapped around with cloth. Beneath the cross or sword are two gowned male(?) figures with short hair. The uppermost one faces right and down, though his body is twisted to face left. He holds a tube, pillar, or rolled scroll. The lowermost figure also holds a tube, pillar, or rolled scroll and is facing down and away, with his(?) left arm bent upward around the tube.
The background sky is dark. The scene may take place in heaven since Lucifer is not yet fallen.
